item.title: New Virus Hot Spots: U.S. Islands from Hawaii to Puerto Rico
item.description: U.S. islands in the Caribbean and the Pacific have growing cases of the coronavirus, which can spike even in places far removed from urban centers when controls are relaxed.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A banner in San Juan, P.R., asks visitors to keep noise down, wear a mask and throw garbage in bins.

item.title: Hurricane Laura Live Updates: Evacuations Near Houston as Texas Prepares
item.description: Forecasters predicted that Laura, which reached hurricane strength on Tuesday, would become a Category 3 storm before making landfall near the Louisiana-Texas border.

item.title: After Jacob Blake Shooting, Scrutiny of Kenosha Police Intensifies
item.description: Protests following the shooting of Mr. Blake, a Black man, by a white police officer reached Madison, Wis., and New York.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman and Richard A. Oppel Jr.
item.media:credit: Carlos Ortiz for The New York Times

item.title: Jerry Falwell Jr.’s Departure Brings Relief on Liberty University’s Campus
item.description: “We almost had a monarchy,” said one of many students who said they supported Mr. Falwell’s exit.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Graham
item.media:credit: Jonathan Drake/Reuters
item.media:description: Jerry Falwell Jr. resigned from his position as president of Liberty University on Tuesday. He suggested he was happy to move on.

item.title: Trump Administration Orders Hospitals to Report Data or Risk Losing Funding
item.description: The administration now says failure to report Covid-19 data to the Department of Health and Human Services could cost hospitals Medicare and Medicaid funding.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:credit: John Moore/Getty Images
item.media:description: Emergency medical workers taking a patient experiencing symptoms of Covid-19 to a hospital in Houston this month.

item.title: National Conventions: The Impeachment Battle Rematch That Wasn’t
item.description: Six months after President Trump’s Senate trial, what was once seen as the battle of a generation has essentially vanished from the political landscape, all but unmentioned at either party’s convention.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: The national conversation is now being dominated by issues that were barely on the radar screen when President Trump’s trial ended.

item.title: Confronting a Powerful Democrat, Ocasio-Cortez Supports Morse
item.description: In using her political action committee to endorse Alex Morse in Massachusetts, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez backed an effort to oust Representative Richard E. Neal, the powerful Ways and Means Committee chairman.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Alex Morse of Holyoke, Mass., is challenging Representative Richard E. Neal in what is expected to be a heated primary election.

item.title: The R.N.C.’s Not-So-Subtle Undertones
item.description: The convention’s first night was a continuation of President Trump’s divisive culture war message.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times

item.title: Republicans Turn to Rescued Hostages to Highlight Trump Foreign Policy
item.description: With a thin record of achievement abroad, President Trump celebrated the releases of Americans held overseas.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump invited the Rev. Andrew Brunson to the Oval Office in October 2018, after he was freed as a hostage in Turkey.

item.title: The Kansas candidate who admitted to revenge porn is back in the race.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: The F.D.A. is expanding use of antibody-rich plasma as a treatment. Does it work?
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: What to Watch For on Night 2 of the RNC: Melania, Eric and Tiffany Trump
item.description: Three of President Trump’s family members will speak tonight, including his wife, Melania.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many speeches will take place at the Mellon Auditorium in Washington.

item.title: For Biden, great Black voter turnout may come down to men.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some like State Representative David Bowen, a Democrat from Milwaukee who is part of a cohort of Black leaders and activists who protested racial inequality after the killing of George Floyd, want to force Democrats including Mr. Biden to be more responsive to its concerns.

item.title: Airline Job Cuts Could Pressure Congress and Trump on Stimulus
item.description: American Airlines said it would furlough 19,000 workers if lawmakers do not extend aid to the industry, which has been hammered by the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi and Ben Casselman
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Josh Ritchie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Passenger airlines received $25 billion to help pay workers during the pandemic, but that aid is ending.

item.title: C.D.C. Now Says People Without Covid-19 Symptoms Do Not Need Testing
item.description: The revision prompted confusion and alarm from experts, who called the move “potentially dangerous.”
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: “If people are getting exposed, and they’re not getting tested, and they’re not isolating, that’s a huge problem,” one doctor said.

item.title: Kansas Candidate Who Admitted to Revenge Porn Is Back in the Race
item.description: Aaron Coleman, 19, had said he was dropping out of the race after winning the Democratic primary election for a Kansas House seat by 14 votes. Now he wants back in.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross

item.title: Immigration Agency Averts Work Force Furloughs, but Deep Cuts Loom
item.description: Plunging revenue from immigration fees nearly forced U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services to furlough more than two-thirds of its work force. Now cuts will come from its operations.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Mike Blake/Reuters
item.media:description: Immigration officers administering the oath during a drive-in naturalization ceremony in Santa Ana, Calif., in July.

item.title: Hee Sook Lee, Founder of BCD Tofu House, Dies at 61
item.description: She spent long nights developing her secret recipe for Korean tofu soup, a dish that became a phenomenon while her restaurant grew into a chain.
item.dc:creator: Gillian Friedman
item.media:credit: Spencer Weiner/Los Angeles Times
item.media:description: Hee Sook Lee in 2007 in Los Angeles outside the original BCD Tofu House in Koreatown. The restaurant eventually expanded to 13 locations in 12 cities across America.

item.title: A Michigan Woman Was Declared Dead, Then Woke Up at a Funeral Home
item.description: Timesha Beauchamp, 20, was taken to the funeral home in a body bag. When she arrived, a worker discovered her breathing with her eyes open.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Waller and Derrick Bryson Taylor

item.title: Melania Trump Returns to Speak at the RNC, Despite Keeping a Low Profile
item.description: The first lady rarely makes public speeches. Allies say this means when she does speak, people are primed to listen.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni, Katie Rogers and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Politically, Melania Trump’s high-profile role in the convention could mean a boost for her husband, President Trump. Campaign aides have been eager for more of her time.

item.title: Justice Dept. Is Set to Execute Native American Prisoner
item.description: Lezmond Mitchell faces the death penalty for his part in the 2001 murder of a Navajo woman and her 9-year-old granddaughter, a case that has raised issues about tribal sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: Hailey Fuchs
item.media:credit: Jonathan J. Cooper/Associated Press
item.media:description: Auska Mitchell holding a photograph of his nephew, Lezmond Mitchell, who is scheduled to be executed on Wednesday.

item.title: Can You Get a Flu Shot Now? Yes, and Doctors Say You Should
item.description: You could help prevent a “twindemic” of influenza and Covid-19, they say. Doctors have specific advice for people over 65, pregnant women and those with egg allergies. Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Concepción de León
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Bryan R. Smith/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Most drugstores now have the flu vaccine in stock, for little or no cost with insurance.

item.title: A convention seafood battle looms as lobster waits in the wings to take on calamari.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman

item.title: Michael Cohen says Trump ‘can’t be trusted’ in a new super PAC ad.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: In an ad, Michael Cohen challenges President Trump’s credibility and calls his claim of upholding law and order “laughable."

item.title: Trump’s supporters dismiss behavior that many of his critics find disqualifying.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters greeted Mr. Trump in Old Forge, Pa., last week.

item.title: Trump says he will nominate Chad Wolf to be secretary of homeland security.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chad Wolf on Capitol Hill in August.

item.title: Why the G.O.P. Punted on a New Party Platform for the 2020 R.N.C.
item.description: The Republican National Committee dispensed with producing a new platform, instead renewing what delegates enacted in 2016 and offering wholehearted support for President Trump, whose campaign also released a 50-point plan outlining “core priorities.”
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Travis Dove
item.media:description: “The Republican Party has and will continue to enthusiastically support the president’s America-first agenda” read the resolution, adopted this past weekend in Charlotte, N.C., before the start of the convention.

item.title: The Pandemic’s Economic Crisis Calls for a Green Recovery
item.description: Rachel Kyte, the dean of the Fletcher School at Tufts University, shows what a climate-focused recovery might look like and why the time to get started is right now.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff

item.title: Pompeo to Deliver R.N.C. Speech From Israel With Eye on 2024
item.description: No sitting secretary of state has addressed a national political convention in at least 75 years.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Debbie Hill
item.media:description: For Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, bolstering Israel serves dual purposes: protecting America’s strongest ally in the volatile Middle East, and appealing to white evangelical voters.

item.title: Republicans mount a revisionist defense of Trump’s record.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin, Alexander Burns and Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump Jr. delivering his address to the Republican National Convention on Monday in Washington.

item.title: A look at Trump’s false claims at the R.N.C. about the virus and the economy.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Jeanna Smialek and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Charlotte Convention Center’s Richardson Ballroom on Monday.

item.title: Joe Segal, Impresario of Live Jazz for 70 Years, Dies at 94
item.description: His Jazz Showcase was a staple in Chicago since 1947, presenting a who’s who of artists, from Charlie Parker to Dee Dee Bridgewater. To the N.E.A., he was a Jazz Master.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:credit: Michael Jackson
item.media:description: Joe Segal in 2003 with a placard for a show by the saxophonist Charles McPherson. Mr. Segal discovered and supported numerous jazz artists.

item.title: The Democrats Are United to Fight Trump, Tensions on Policy Are Looming
item.description: The Democratic National Convention showcased Joe Biden’s goals on issues like health care, climate change and the economy. But there is plenty of daylight between his plans and what progressives want to see.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Kaplan and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: At the Democratic National Convention, the policy agenda for Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic nominee, was sketched out in broad strokes to help him appeal to as wide a universe of voters as possible.

item.title: Heat, Smoke and Covid Are Battering the Workers Who Feed America
item.description: Climate change is piling on to the hazards already faced by California farm laborers, some of the country's poorest, most neglected workers.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Brian L. Frank

item.title: Our TV critic assesses Night 1 and its ‘decibel champion,’ Kimberly Guilfoyle.
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump Jr., right, looked on as Kimberly Guilfoyle delivered her address to the Republican National Convention during a preshow taping in Washington on Monday.

item.title: Trump offers rare praise for CNN after it broadcast the R.N.C. largely uninterrupted.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: Conflicting statements on Erdogan by Trump and the State Dept. highlight a disconnect.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump called President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey “very good,” but the State Department denounced Mr. Erdogan’s recent meeting with leaders of Hamas.

item.title: California Fires Live Updates: Firefighters Make Progress in ‘Marathon’ Battle
item.description: As some evacuation orders lift, a sheriff warned that “this is a time when some people will realize they no longer have homes.”
item.media:credit: Ian C. Bates for The New York Times
item.media:description: Only a chimney remained at a home destroyed by the L.N.U. Lightning Complex fire in Napa County, Calif., on Monday.

item.title: DeJoy defends postal changes as Trump continues to attack voting by mail.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Louis DeJoy, the postmaster general, was sworn in for a hearing before the House Oversight and Reform Committee on Monday.

item.title: Police Face Off Against Protesters in Wisconsin
item.description: Protesters and law enforcement officers clashed in Kenosha, Wis., over the shooting of Jacob Blake, a Black man, by a white police officer.
item.dc:creator: Erik Ljung, Katie G. Nelson and McKenzie Marshall
item.media:credit: Carlos Ortiz for The New York Times

item.title: Here’s how to watch the convention on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor

item.title: Trump shifts into listening mode, if only briefly.
item.description: On the first night of the Republican National Convention, speakers celebrated President Trump and warned of the economic devastation they believe a Biden administration will bring.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer

item.title: California Fires: Why This Year Is Different
item.description: Tuesday: The vast scale of wildfires rampaging across the state is an indication of what’s to come.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: The L.N.U. Lightning Complex Fire has forced evacuations in and around Vacaville.

item.title: Day 2 of the G.O.P. Convention: Schedule, Speakers and How to Watch
item.description: The event’s second night will feature Melania Trump, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Senator Rand Paul.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: People watched the Republican National Convention at a restaurant in West Palm Beach, Fla., on Monday. The second night will include a mix of speakers including several Trump family members and top Republican lawmakers.

item.title: Revisionist History at the R.N.C.
item.description: On the first night of the Republican National Convention, speaker after speaker tried to revise reality.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Nick Corasaniti

item.title: Virus Laggards
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Oscar Del Pozo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Covid-19 Live Updates: C.D.C. Changes Testing Guidance to Exclude People Without Symptoms, Worrying Experts
item.description: Two people in Europe are found to have been reinfected with the virus. Researchers also say a conference in Boston in February may have spread it to tens of thousands.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Where the Produce Includes Pepperoni: The Pizza Farm
item.description: This Midwestern staple has grown ever more popular in the pandemic, bringing farmers and diners together in a socially distanced summer destination.
item.dc:creator: Julia Moskin
item.media:credit: Narayan Mahon for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Luna Valley Farm in Decorah, Iowa, and other pizza farms across the country, the crops become toppings on summer nights.

item.title: Trump’s Fights Are Their Fights. They Have His Back Unapologetically.
item.description: Many supporters of President Trump said in interviews that he had succeeded on issues that matter to them. And they dismissed as unimportant the behavior that critics say makes him unfit for office.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters like Robin Sinsabaugh of North Carolina view President Trump’s character and policies through a fundamentally different prism than his opponents do.

item.title: Flu Season Could Make Coronavirus Testing Delays Even Worse
item.description: The nation’s testing efforts will be further overwhelmed once influenza, R.S.V. and other seasonal viruses arrive.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.media:credit: Bryan R. Smith/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Doctors won’t be able to diagnose patients on a hunch. “The flu season is a bit of a ticking time bomb,” said one expert. “We are all waiting and trying to prepare as best we can.”
